{{expert|Bible|reason=the meaning of the chapter appears to be a controversial issue|date=September 2015}} {{Bible chapter|letname= Leviticus 18 |previouslink= Leviticus 17 |previousletter= chapter 17 |nextlink= Leviticus 19 |nextletter= chapter 19 |book= [[Book of Leviticus]] |biblepart=[[Old Testament]] | booknum= 3 |category= [[Torah]] | filename= Book of Exodus Chapter 28-2 (Bible Illustrations by Sweet Media).jpg | size=250px | name= Biblical illustrations by Sweet Media, 1984 |caption=
"[[Tabernacle]]", ''Biblical illustrations'', Sweet Media, 1984
}} '''Leviticus 18''' is the eighteenth chapter of the [[Book of Leviticus]] in the [[Hebrew Bible]] or the [[Old Testament]] of the [[Christian]] [[Bible]]. It narrates part of the instructions which, according to the Bible, were given to [[Moses]] by God on [[biblical Mount Sinai]]. The chapter deals with a number of sexual activities considered unclean or [[Abomination (Bible)|abominable]]. Although the chapter is principally concerned with [[incest]], it also contains laws related to [[bestiality]] and "lying with a man as with a woman." This single reference in verse 22 has, in recent years, been a focus of debate among Christians and Jews regarding [[homosexual]] activity (see [[Homosexuality and Christianity]] and [[Jewish views of homosexuality]]).{{cn|date=July 2017}} Leviticus 18 is generally regarded as part of the [[Holiness Code]] of Leviticus 11–26, and its sexual prohibitions are largely paralleled by Leviticus 20 (except that chapter has more emphasis on punishment). == Text == The original text of Leviticus 18, like that of most of the [[Hebrew Bible]], was written in Hebrew. The oldest extant versions of the text in Hebrew are found in the [[Dead Sea Scrolls]], the [[Samaritan Pentateuch]], and the [[Masoretic Text]]. An ancient Greek translation from the third century BCE, the [[Septuagint]], also exists. Since the addition of chapter divisions in the thirteenth century CE, this [[Chapters and verses of the Bible|chapter]] is divided into 30 verses. The chapter begins with God speaking to Moses (verse 1) and giving him a message for the Israelites (2), warning them to keep God's laws rather than Canaanite or Egyptian practices (3–5). Then follows a list of people with whom sex is forbidden to do family relationships (6–19). Verse 20 prohibits sexual relations with a neighbor's wife, and 21 prohibits passing one's children through a fire to [[Moloch]]. 22 is the famous verse about "lying with a man," discussed below, while 23 forbids bestiality. The final verses (24–30) warn that breaking these laws will produce defilement, and that the [[Canaanites]] are about to be displaced from the land of [[Canaan]] as a result of following these practices, and warn of a similar fate for the Israelites if they fall into these practices. ==Incest== {{Main|Incest in the Bible}} The Bible lists several types of relationship which it regards as incestuous unions; one list appears in the [[Deuteronomic Code]], and two lists occur in the [[Holiness Code]] of [[Leviticus]]. These lists only mention relationships with female relatives; excluding [[lesbianism]], which implies that the list is addressed to men. These lists then compare as follows: (blue = forbidden for men only, pink = forbidden for women only, purple = forbidden for both men and women): {|border="1" class="wikitable" style="text-align:right" |- |colspan="3"| ||Leviticus 18||Leviticus 20||Deuteronomy |- |colspan="3"|Grandparent's spouse (including other grandparent)||style="background-color:#FF70B8"| || || |- |colspan="2" rowspan="2"|Parent's spouse||Parent||style="background-color:#6090FF"| || ||rowspan="2" style="background-color:#6090FF"| |- |Stepparent||style="background-color:#4c387f"| ||style="background-color:#4c387f"| |- |colspan="3"|Parent-in-law||style="background-color:#4c387f"| ||style="background-color:#FF70B8"| ||style="background-color:#6090FF"| |- |rowspan="3"|Uncle/Aunt||colspan="2"|Parent's sibling||style="background-color:#6090FF"| ||style="background-color:#6090FF"| || |- |rowspan="2"|Uncle's/Aunt's Spouse||Father's sibling's spouse||style="background-color:#6090FF"| ||style="background-color:#6090FF"| || |- |Mother's sibling's spouse||colspan="3"| |- |rowspan="3"|Parent's child||colspan="2"|Half-Sibling (mother's side)|| || ||rowspan="3" style="background-color:#4c387f"| |- |rowspan="2"|Father's child||Sibling||rowspan="2" style="background-color:#4c387f"| || |- |Half-Sibling (father's side)||style="background-color:#4c387f"| |- |colspan="3"|Step sibling||colspan="3"| |- |colspan="3"|Sibling-in-law (if the spouse was still alive)||style="background-color:#4c387f"| || || |- |rowspan="3"|Nephew/Niece||colspan="2"|Sibling's child||style="background-color:#FF70B8"| ||style="background-color:#FF70B8"| || |- |rowspan="2"|Nephew/Niece-in-law||Spouse's Brother's Child||style="background-color:#FF70B8"| ||style="background-color:#FF70B8"| || |- |Spouse's Sister's Child||colspan="3"| |- |colspan="2" rowspan="2"|Spouse's child||Child||style="background-color:#FF70B8"| || ||rowspan="2" style="background-color:#FF70B8"| |- |Stepchild||style="background-color:#4c387f"| ||style="background-color:#4c387f"| |- |colspan="3"|Child-in-law||style="background-color:#4c387f"| ||style="background-color:#6090FF"| ||style="background-color:#FF70B8"| |- |colspan="3"|Spouse's grandchild (including grandchild)||style="background-color:#6090FF"| || || |- |} One feature of all the lists is that sexual activity between a man and his own daughter is not explicitly forbidden. The [[Talmud]] argues that this is because the prohibition was ''obvious'', especially given the proscription against a relationship with a granddaughter.Yebamot 3a The shortness of the list in Leviticus 20, and especially of that in Deuteronomy, are explained by classical Jewish scholarship as being due to the ''obviousness'' of the missing prohibitions.''Jewish Encyclopedia'', s.v. ''Incest''[[Samuel ben Meir]], ''Commentary'', ad loc. Note also that the explicit prohibition against engaging in sexual activity with "both a woman and her daughter",{{bibleverse||Leviticus|18:17|}} implicitly forbids sexual activity between a man and his daughter. Some [[biblical criticism|biblical scholars]] have instead proposed that it was originally in the list, but was then accidentally left out from the copy on which modern versions of the text ultimately depend, due to a mistake by the scribe.Cheyne and Black, Encyclopaedia Biblica, ''Marriage : choice of bride'' Apart from the questionable case of a man marrying his daughter, the list in Leviticus 18 roughly produces the same rules as were followed in early [[Pre-Islamic Arabia|pre-Islamic Arabic]] culture. However, most tribal nations also disliked [[exogamy|exogamous]] marriage—marriage to completely unrelated people. In several prominent cases in the Torah, the incest rules are ignored in favour of marriage to a close relative; [[Jacob]] is described as having married his first wife's sister,{{bibleverse||Genesis|29:16|}}{{bibleverse||Genesis|29:23|}}{{bibleverse||Genesis|29:28|}} and [[Abraham]] as having a father in common with [[Sarah]]{{bibleverse||Genesis|20:12|}} (rather than a mother, which would have been permitted by the list). These are not seen as illegal marriages as the incest laws were not given until Moses. ==Homosexuality== {{details|The Bible and homosexuality|Biblical law in Christianity}} The text of 18:22: {{quote| "Thou shalt not lie with mankind, as with womankind: it is abomination." [[King James Version]] "You shall not lie with a male as with a woman; it is an abomination." [[Revised Standard Version]] and [[English Standard Version]] "Do not have sexual relations with a man as one does with a woman: that is detestable". [[Contemporary English Version]]}} The Hebrew wording of Leviticus 18:22 has been generally interpreted as prohibiting some or all [[Gay sexual practices|homosexual acts]], although which precise acts, and in which situations, is a matter of ongoing scholarly debate.For an overview of some of the scholarly views on the question, see Walsh, Jerome T. "Leviticus 18:22 and 20:13: Who Is Doing What to Whom?" ''Journal of Biblical Literature'', vol. 120, no. 2, 2001, pp. 201–209. {{jstor|3268292}}. Some authorsGreenberg 1988:191, Wenham 1979:259, Kahn 1984:49 state that verse 22 condemns "[[homosexuality]]" or "homosexual relations" and other authors maintaining that it condemns only males penetrating males ([[Anal sex|anal intercourse]]).Babylonian Talmud Sanhedrin 54a and b; Josephus, Against Apion 2.199; and Philo, Abraham 135. Some modern authors stating this view include Alter 2004:623, 632; Boyarin 1995:339, 343; Brooten 1996:61; Cohen 1990:6; Daube 1986:447; Milgrom 2000:1568; Olyan 1994:185; Thurston 1990:16; and Walsh 2001:208. The Talmud maintains the law prohibits all male homosexual activity including [[pederasty]]. Since the practice is allotted the death penalty for both the active and the passive partners in Leviticus 20http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0320.htm the law appears to have only applied when both participants were men above the age of majority, which is set at 20 years old in the Torah.http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0327.htm [[Lesbian]]ism is not explicitly prohibited in the Torah; however, the rabbi and Jewish scholar [[Maimonides]] ruled in the twelfth century that lesbianism was prohibited nonetheless and deserving of punishment by beating.{{Cite news |url=http://www.myjewishlearning.com/article/homosexuality-and-halakhah/ |title=Homosexuality and Halakhah (Jewish Law)|work=My Jewish Learning|access-date=2017-03-02 |language=en-us}} == Judaism == * The whole chapter is part of the [[weekly Torah portion]] ([[parashah]]) ''[[Acharei Mot]]'' ({{hebrew|אַחֲרֵי מוֹת}}) which comprises Leviticus 16:1–18:30.[http://www.hebcal.com/sedrot/ Parashah calendar] == Notes == {{Reflist}} == References == * Alter, Robert, The five books of Moses: a translation with commentary, 2004 * Boyarin, Daniel, "Are there any Jews in ‘The History of Sexuality’?", Journal of the History of Sexuality, Vol 5 no 3 (1995) * Brooten, Bernadette, Love Between Women: Early Christian Responses to Female Homoeroticism, 1996 * Cohen, Martin, "The Biblical Prohibition of Homosexual Intercourse," Journal of Homosexuality, Vol 19(4) (1990) * Daube, David, "The Old Testament Prohibitions of Homosexuality." Zeitschrift der Savigny-Stiftung fur Rechtsgeschichte Romantische Abteilung 103 (1986) * Gagnon, Robert, The Bible and Homosexual Practice: Texts and Hermeneutics, 2001 * Greenberg, David, The Construction of Homosexuality,1988 * Kahn, Yoel, "Judaism and Homosexuality: The Traditionalist/ Progressive Debate," Homosexuality and Religion, ed Richard Hasbany 1984 * Milgrom, Jacob, Leviticus 17–22, 2000 * Olyan, Saul, "And with a Male You Shall Not Lie the Lying Down of a Woman": On the Meaning and Significance of Leviticus 18:22 and 20:13", Journal of the History of Sexuality, Vol 5, no 2, (1994) * Thurston, Thomas, "Leviticus 18:22 and the Prohibition of Homosexual Acts," in Homophobia and the Judeo-Christian Tradition, ed. by Michael L. Stemmeler & J. Michael Clark, 1990 * Walsh, Jerome, "Leviticus 18:22 and 20:13: Who Is Doing What To Whom?" Journal of Biblical Literature, Vol 120, No 2, (2001) Also available [http://www.sbl-site.org/Publications/JBL/JBL1202.pdf here]. * Wenham, Gordon, The Book of Leviticus, 1979 * Wold, Donald, Out of Order: Homosexuality in the Bible and the Ancient Near East, 1998 * [http://headcoverings-by-devorah.com/HebEngTaNaKh27.html Hebrew phrasing] for Lev 18. * [https://archive.is/20021207052423/http://www.anova.org/sev/ The Great Books], for NRSV text. * Blue Letter Bible's [http://www.tgm.org/bible.htm Bible Lookup Tools] were used to derive passage citations. * [http://blueletterbible.org/Comm/jfb/Lev/Lev018.html Robert Jamieson's Commentary on Lev 18]. {{unreferenced|date=July 2015}} [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] [[Tribe (Native American)|tribes]] have maintained numerous [[Native American mythology|mythologies]] regarding deities throughout their histories. Native American belief systems include many sacred [[narrative]]s. Such spiritual stories are deeply based in Nature and are rich with the symbolism of seasons, weather, plants, animals, earth, water, sky & fire. Deities play a large part in these narratives.
== [[Abenaki]] == *[[Azeban]] - [[trickster]] *[[Bmola]] - [[bird]] spirit *[[Gluskab]] - kind protector of humanity *[[Malsumis]] - cruel, evil god *[[Tabaldak]] - the creator
== [[Algonquian peoples|Algonquian]] == *[[Gitche Manitou]] - Great Spirit *[[Matchi Manitou]] - Evil Spirit
== [[Blackfoot religion]] == *[[Apistotookii]] - Creator *[[Napi (god)|Napi]] - trickster
== [[Haida mythology|Haida]] == *[[Gyhldeptis]] *[[Lagua]] *[[Nañkî'lsLas]] *[[Sin (Haida)|Sin]] *[[Ta'xet]] *[[Tia (goddess)|Tia]]

== Inuit == {{Main|Inuit mythology}} * [[Igaluk]] - lunar deity * [[Nanook]] - master of bears * [[Nerrivik]] - sea mother and food provider * [[Pinga]] - Goddess of the hunt, fertility, and medicine * [[Sedna (deity)|Sedna]] - sea Goddess, ruler of the underworld * [[Torngasoak]] - sky god

== [[Mi'kmaq people|Mi'kmaq]] == *[[Niskam]]
== Navajo == {{Main|Diné Bahaneʼ}} * {{spell-nv|[[Asdzą́ą́ Nádleehé]]}} - creation deity, changing woman * {{spell-nv|[[Bikʼeh Hózhǫ́]]}} - personification of speech * {{spell-nv|[[Haashchʼéé Oołtʼohí]]}} - deity of the hunt * {{spell-nv|[[Haashchʼééłtiʼí]]}} - the Talking god, god of the dawn and the east * {{spell-nv|[[Hashchʼéoghan]]}} - the House-god, god of evening and the west * {{spell-nv|[[Niltsi]]}} - Wind god * {{spell-nv|[[Tó Neinilii]]}} - ‘water sprinkler’, rain god * {{spell-nv|[[Jóhonaaʼéí]]}} - sun * {{spell-nv|[[Yoołgai Asdzą́ą́]]}} - ‘white-shell woman’, lunar deity * [[Coyote (Navajo mythology)]] - trickster god

==[[Snohomish tribe|Snohomish]]== * [[Dohkwibuhch]] - creator
==[[Taíno]] mythology== * [[Yaya (god)]], supreme God/Great Spirit in [[Taíno]] mythology. * [[Yayael]], the son of Yaya. * [[Atabey (goddess)]], Mother goddess of fresh water and fertility. Female counterpart of the god [[Yúcahu]]. * [[Yúcahu]], the masculine spirit of fertility in Taíno mythology along with his mother [[Atabey]] who was his feminine counterpart. * [[Guabancex]], the top Storm Goddess; the Lady of the Winds who also deals out earthquakes and other such disasters of nature. * [[Juracán]], the [[zemi]] or deity of chaos and disorder believed to control the weather, particularly hurricanes. * [[Guatauva]], the god of thunder and lightning who is also responsible for rallying the other storm gods. * [[Coatrisquie]], the torrential downpour Goddess, the terrible [[Taíno]] storm servant of Guabancex and side-kick of thunder God Guatauva. * [[Bayamanaco]], Old man fire; the [[Taíno]] spirit of [[Cohoba]] and guardian of the secrets of sweet potato bread. * [[Boinayel]], twin god that looked after rain, rain, and more rain. * [[Marohu]], the sunny god of good weather; Boinayel's twin brother. * [[Maketaori Guayaba]], the god of [[Coaybay]] or Coabey, the land of the dead. * [[Opiyel Guabiron]], a dog-shaped god that watched over the dead; often associated with the Greek [[Cerberus]].

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=April 2018}} {{Orphan|date=March 2018}} {{more citations needed|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox writer | name = Manmohan Bawa
ਮਨਮੋਹਨ ਬਾਵਾ | image = [[File:Manmohan Bawa.jpg|Manmohan Bawa]] | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_date = 18 August 1932 | birth_place = Amritsar | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Novelist, short-story writer, author of maps and travel guides | nationality = Indian | period = | genre = Travel, Novels based on History | subject = | movement = | spouse = | influences = | influenced = | signature = | website = }} '''Manmohan Bawa''' ({{lang-pa|ਮਨਮੋਹਨ ਬਾਵਾ}};) is an award-winning{{cite web|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/ludhiana/community/novelist-manmohan-bawa-gets-rupinder-mann-memorial-award/56925.html|website=tribuneindia.com|title=Novelist Manmohan Bawa gets Rupinder Mann Memorial Award|accessdate=2017-11-02}} writer, painter and a cartographer from [[Punjab, India|Punjab]] and [[Himachal Pradesh]], [[India]]. He has written novels, anthologies of short stories, [[travel literature|travelogues]], travel guides in addition to publishing trekking maps of some [[Himalayas|Himalayan]] regions. Bawa was born in 1932 in Verowal, district [[Amritsar]]. He spent first five years in Verowal, and the following 5 years in [[Dhuri]] in erstwhile [[Patiala State|Patiala state]], eventually moving to [[New Delhi]] in 1942. Passing grade 10 in 1947, Bawa went on to get a [[Master of Arts|Master of Art]] degree in history. Bawa expressed interested in art and travelling from a young age. Due to very hard financial family circumstances, he started working as an apprentice artist at the age of 16. He worked as a graphic artist for 25 years in different presses and firms, including an American firm, beginning in 1948 at a salary of [[Rupee|Rs]] 50 per month. He eventually got tired of working and left the job in 1973 Along with his brothers, Bawa purchased a hotel to make living and to live a free and full life, pursuing other interests i.e. painting, traveling, trekking in the Himalayas and writing. Though his first book of short story was published in 1962, Bawa only started writing seriously at the age of 55. His interest in writing being history and mythology, his first book of short story, Ajat Sundari was published in 1990 .Along with history the themes of his writing were [[adivasi]]s and [[dalit]]s. He published several [[Travel literature|travelogues]], short story collections, novels in [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] and one book on history and Indian mythology. Bawa is also brother of the famous painter [[Manjit Bawa]]. == Awards == {{Expand section|date=November 2017}} * Rupinder Mann Memorial Award * Kusmanjali Award * Odisha Sahitya Academy Award == {{cleanup|date=August 2013|reason=Article is not written in an encyclopedic style; reads like a press release biography. If subject is noteworthy enough for inclusion, more information should be added and divided into sections.}} '''Michelle Stith''', née Henderson, also known as '''Chel Stith''', is as of August 6, 2005 President<ref>{{cite news | last = Staff | first = | coauthors = | title = Dollars and sense: Bloggers take on costs of Scientology | work = [[Bakersfield Californian]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = August 6, 2005 | url = | accessdate = }} </ref> of the [[Church of Scientology]] of [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]]. Stith has been quoted in the press answering questions about Scientology and its practices. According to Scientology publications, Stith has attained the [[Operating Thetan]] level of "OT III Expanded".<ref>New OT III Expanded., ''Freewinds 47'', September 1, 2002. Listed as "Chel Stith".</ref> In 2005, she stated that she had been a member of Scientology for thirty-four years.<ref name="kozlowski" />
Stith commented on the 2004 production of ''[[A Very Merry Unauthorized Children's Scientology Pageant]]'', stating that Scientology did not want to protest the theatre production, and was quoted as saying "This is not litigation material."<ref>{{cite news | last = Kendt | first = Rob | coauthors = | title = Two Hollywood theater troupes get religion | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = November 1, 2004 | url = | accessdate = }} </ref>
In July 2005, Stith defended Scientology in media sources, after the [[Tom Cruise]] incident with [[Matt Lauer]] on ''[[Today (NBC program)|The Today Show]]'' where [[Brooke Shields]]' use of medication for [[postpartum depression]] was discussed. Stith called criticism by the media "hogwash", and stated "This is a very practical religion."<ref>{{cite news | last = Staff | first = | coauthors = | title = The Religion of the stars | work = [[Bakersfield Californian]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = July 26, 2005 | url = | accessdate = }} </ref> In August 2005, Stith was quoted as asserting that Scientology has 40,000 members in the Los Angeles area alone.<ref name="kozlowski">{{cite news |last=Kozlowski |first=Carl |coauthors= |title=Debunking a movement: Exposing some of the unsavory claims that Tom Cruise, John Travolta and other celebrities would rather you didn't know about Scientology |work=Pasadena Weekly |pages= |language= |publisher= |date=August 5, 2005 |url=http://www.pasadenaweekly.com/features/feature/feature.html |accessdate= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050806235055/http://www.pasadenaweekly.com/features/feature/feature.html |archivedate=August 6, 2005 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2005, Stith has asserted that Scientology has grown more internationally in the past five years, than in all previous years combined, and that its current membership numbered 10 million.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Chiorazzi | first = Tory | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Delve into Dianetics: The visionary, sometimes controversial world of scientology is alive in L.A | newspaper = Daily Trojan | pages = 1–3 | year = | date = September 13, 2005 | url = }} </ref>
Stith stated that her sister was a member of the [[Sea Org]], and has five children, when asked about rumors of coerced abortions within Scientology.<ref name="kozlowski" /> She went on to note that she herself is a mother of four, works as an artist, and also works forty-hours per week for Scientology.<ref name="kozlowski" /> In 2006, Stith's pregnancy and delivery was reported on in the ''[[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Chicago Daily Herald]]'', in a report analyzing the [[Silent birth|silent birth practices of Scientology]], and how this would apply to [[Katie Holmes]].<ref name="sotonoff">{{cite news | last = Sotonoff | first = Jamie | coauthors = | title = Shhhhhh! Silent birth in progress Could you deliver a baby without uttering a sound? Many Scientologists have - and Katie Holmes may do the same | work = [[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Chicago Daily Herald]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = March 16, 2006 | url = | accessdate = }} </ref> The birth of Stith's fifth child, a boy, was described, in which Stith refused painkillers, and there was silence in the delivery room.<ref name="sotonoff" /> All of the medical personnel were also quiet, and when the baby was born, the [[physician]] whispered to Stith "It's a boy."<ref name="sotonoff" /> When asked about [[L. Ron Hubbard]]'s own use of medications, and the presence of certain medications in the coroner's toxicology report after Hubbard's death, Stith stated: "He might have been taking some medicine for asthma, but he certainly was not under any medicine for psychiatric reasons."<ref name="kozlowski" />

[[File:Kopimi k.svg|thumb|The Kopimi symbol]] [[File:Kopimizm.svg|thumb|Ctrl-C, Ctrl-V]] The '''Missionary Church of Kopimism''' (in [[Swedish language|Swedish]] ''Missionerande Kopimistsamfundet''), is a congregation of [[file sharing|file sharers]] who believe that copying information is a sacred virtue<ref name="Jackson" /><ref name="await" /><ref name="CITROME" /> and was founded by Isak Gerson,<ref name=bbc/> a 19-year-old philosophy student,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sinnreich|first=Aram|date=2016-04-02|title=Sharing in spirit: Kopimism and the digital Eucharist|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/1369118X.2015.1036766|journal=Information, Communication & Society|volume=19|issue=4|pages=504–517|doi=10.1080/1369118X.2015.1036766|issn=1369-118X}}</ref> and Gustav Nipe in [[Uppsala, Sweden]] in the autumn of 2010.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://kopimistsamfundetus.wordpress.com/2012/01/09/press-release-from-the-church-of-kopimism/|title=Press Release from the Church of Kopimism|date=2012-01-09|website=First United Church of Kopimism, US|access-date=2016-10-22}}</ref> The Church, based in Sweden, has been officially recognized by the [[Legal, Financial and Administrative Services Agency]] as a religious community in January 2012, after three application attempts.<ref name=bbc/><ref name="Ernesto"/>
Gerson has denied any connection between the Church and filesharing site [[The Pirate Bay]],<ref name="Privitera">{{cite web|last=Privitera|first=Salvatore|title=File-sharing as a religion, do we really need it?|url=http://pazuzu-uzu.blogspot.com/2012/01/file-sharing-as-religion-do-we-really.html|accessdate=29 January 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504031906/http://pazuzu-uzu.blogspot.com/2012/01/file-sharing-as-religion-do-we-really.html|archivedate=4 May 2014|df=}}</ref> but both groups are associated with the Swedish art and hacking collective [[Piratbyrån]].
== Name == The name Kopimism derives from the words ''copy'' and ''me'' which are the fundamental roots of the Church's beliefs and calls for an invitation to copy information. The work "Kopimi" first showed up on a pirate Agency Forum.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://kopimistsamfundetus.wordpress.com/about/|title=About|date=2012-01-09|newspaper=First United Church of Kopimism, US|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-22}}</ref> Isak Gerson, one of the core founders saw something beautiful and theological in this concept of "copy me"<ref>Gerson I (2014a) Interview with Gerson. By Nilsson PE, Upssala, 7 May</ref> and argued that the digital sharing of data is a fundamental act in our universe through the reproduction and copying of cells, DNA, and genes<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Nilsson|first=Per-Erik|last2=Enkvist|first2=Victoria|date=2016-08-01|title=Techniques of religion-making in Sweden: The case of the Missionary Church of Kopimism|url=http://crr.sagepub.com/content/4/2/141|journal=Critical Research on Religion|language=en|volume=4|issue=2|pages=141–155|doi=10.1177/2050303215613145|issn=2050-3032}}</ref> and that the entirety of the internet is essentially for sharing.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=John|first=Nicholas A.|date=2013-03-01|title=Sharing and Web 2.0: The emergence of a keyword|url=http://nms.sagepub.com/content/15/2/167|journal=New Media & Society|language=en|volume=15|issue=2|pages=167–182|doi=10.1177/1461444812450684|issn=1461-4448}}</ref>
Gerson has been credited with once saying, "The only thing we can do as Christians now, I suppose, is to do what Jesus tried doing – and do it better."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dagensseglora.se/2014/01/08/vi-har-ett-lofte-om-att-allting-ska-bli-battre/|title=Dagens Seglora - Vi har ett löfte om att allting ska bli bättre|last=Seglora|first=Dagens|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref>
==Tenets== The followers of the religion are called ''Kopimists'' from ''copy me''. A "Kopimist" or "Kopimist intellectual" is a person who has the philosophical belief that all information should be freely distributed and unrestricted. This philosophy opposes the monopolization of knowledge in all its forms, such as copyright, and encourages file sharing of all types of media including music, movies, TV shows, and software.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.revolutimes.com/2012/01/06/sweden-recognizes-file-sharing-as-a-religion/ |title=Sweden Recognizes File Sharing as a Religion |date=4 January 2012 |first=Jenny |last=Worman |publisher=RevoluTimes |accessdate=2 February 2012}}</ref> In fact, the act of withholding and economizing information through copyright is against the sacredness of information.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=John|first=Nicholas A.|last2=Sützl|first2=Wolfgang|date=2016-04-02|title=The rise of ‘sharing’ in communication and media studies|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/1369118X.2015.1115888|journal=Information, Communication & Society|volume=19|issue=4|pages=437–441|doi=10.1080/1369118X.2015.1115888|issn=1369-118X}}</ref> In its spiritual emphasis on copying as an ideal, Kopimism shares values with Chinese aesthetic traditions, in which "copying is valued not only as a learning tool (as it is in the West) but as artistically satisfying in its own right," a concept also called ''duplitecture''.<ref>{{Citation|last = Thompson |first = Clive |title = Imitation Can Be the Sincerest Form of Innovation |newspaper = Wired |date = 27 February 2013 |url =https://www.wired.com/opinion/2013/02/clive-thompson-imitation/ | accessdate = 2010-03-10}}</ref>
According to the church, "In our belief, communication is sacred."<ref name="Jackson" /> No belief in gods or supernatural phenomena apart from [[Kopimi]] itself is mentioned on their web site. ''[[Control-C|CTRL+C]]'' and ''[[Control-V|CTRL+V]]'', the common computer shortcut keys for "Copy" and "Paste," are considered sacred symbols. Some groups believe that [[Kopimi]] is considered to be a god, and others believing it to be a sacred symbol and spirit residing within every living being.
The community also holds a religious service known as "kopyacting" in which information is distributed to the believers using photocopiers.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Neethu|first=R|year=November 2013|title=My Religion: My ‘Copy’ ‘Right’|url=http://nopr.niscair.res.in/handle/123456789/24560|journal=Journal of Intellectual Property Rights|volume=18|pages=566–575|via=NISCAIR Online Periodicals Repository}}</ref>
According to the Kopimist constitution:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kopimistsamfundet.org/main/kopimist-constitution |title=Kopimist Constitution |work=The First Church of Kopimism for the USA |year=2012 |accessdate=1 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120513044913/http://www.kopimistsamfundet.org/main/kopimist-constitution |archivedate=13 May 2012 |df= }}</ref> * Copying of information is ethically right; * Dissemination of information is ethically right; * Copymixing is a sacred kind of copying, more so than the perfect, digital copying, because it expands and enhances the existing wealth of information; * Copying or remixing information communicated by another person is seen as an act of respect and a strong expression of acceptance and Kopimistic faith; * The Internet is holy (Not generally accepted by churches run by the Maesters); * Code is law.
On January 5, 2012, Kopimism was accepted by Sweden as a legitimate religion with an estimated 4,000 members.<ref name=":0" /> The religion's association with illegal [[Legal aspects of file sharing|file sharing]] has been said not to be a sign that illegal file-sharing will be excused from Sweden's zero-tolerance approach to the controversial matter.<ref name=bbc/>
== International locations == Kopimism has also taken root in multiple nations, including:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2012/05/09/kopimism-file-sharing/|title=Kopimism: File-Sharing Religion Takes Root in the U.S.|last=Fitzpatrick|first=Alex|website=Mashable|access-date=2016-10-22}}</ref> * Canada * Japan * Israel * United States of America (including in the state of Illinois in the United States where Kopimism has registered as a non profit 503(c) organization in the form of a church.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eds.a.ebscohost.com/eds/detail/detail?sid=7ea7877c-6d27-4ee4-862a-344a93e38c73@sessionmgr4007&vid=0&hid=4105&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWRzLWxpdmU=#AN=295687.20120209&db=bwh|title=A Pirate Walks Into a Church: Kopimism and the Sacred Act of File-Sharing (...: Start Your Search!|website=eds.a.ebscohost.com|access-date=2016-10-22}}</ref>)
==First wedding== On April 28, 2012, the Missionary Church of Kopimism held their first wedding.<ref name="Wedding"/> The wedding took place in [[Belgrade, Serbia]], between a [[Romanian people|Romanian]] woman and an [[Italian people|Italian]] man. The holy ceremony was conducted by a Kopimistic Op, wearing a [[Guy Fawkes mask]], while a computer read vows and some of Kopimism's central beliefs aloud.<ref>https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2012/05/07/til-delete-do-us-part-first-couple-married-under-swedish-file-sharing-religion</ref>
The church declared: "We are very happy today. Love is all about sharing. A married couple shares everything with each other. Hopefully, they will copy and remix some DNA-cells and create a new human being. That is the spirit of Kopimism. Feel the love and share that information. Copy all of its holiness."
Gerson, the missionary leader of the Church of Kopimism, attended as a witness during the wedding.
== Controversies == Both founders, Gerson and Nipe have had an extensive background in online activism and served as major players in the Swedish Anti-Piracy Movement<ref>Dahlstrom F (2011) Han vill att fildelning ska klassas som religion. Uppsalatidningen, 8 April.</ref> which caused many journalists and government officials in Sweden to speculate on the real goals of the creation of this organization.
There was severe backlash amongst the media and Christian journals in 2011 after the founders first submitted their application for registering as a religion as journalists condemned the Missionary Church of Kopimism as "a political adventure",<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=De vill fildela i skydd av religionen|last=Zetterman|first=J|date=March 22, 2012|work=Dagen|access-date=|via=EBSCOHost}}</ref> "a PR stunt",<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=La˚t oss starta en religion! Forsamlingar klarar sig utan myndighetens forsyn|last=Dareberg|first=L|date=February 1, 2012|work=Sydsvenskan|access-date=|via=EBSCOHost}}</ref> and "a devaluation of religion".<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Kammarkollegiet undergraver religionsfriheten|last=Editorial|first=|date=January 12, 2012|work=Kyrkans tidning|access-date=|via=EBSCOHost}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Anti-copyright]] * [[Culture vs. Copyright]] * [[Gift economy]] * [[Information wants to be free]] * [[List of new religious movements]] * [[Parody religion]]

{{More citations needed|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox comics character and title | character_name = Mister Terrific (Michael Holt) | image = Jsa76.jpg | caption = The Modern Age Mister Terrific on the cover of ''[[Justice Society of America|JSA]]'' #76
Art by [[Alex Ross]]. | publisher = [[DC Comics]] | debut = ''[[Spectre (DC Comics character)|Spectre]]'' (vol. 3) #54 | debutmo = June | debutyr = 1997 | creators = [[John Ostrander]]
[[Tom Mandrake]] | alter_ego = Michael Holt | species = [[Human]] | alliances = [[Justice Society of America]]
[[Checkmate (comics)|Checkmate]]
Terrifics
[[Justice League]] | partners = | aliases = Third-smartest man on Earth, White King, White King's Bishop | powers = Genius-level intellect
Olympic-level athlete
Master martial artist
Undetectable by modern technology
Extensive nanotechnology in mask and costume for a variety of sensory, communication, and database retrieval functions
T-Spheres that function as computers, holographic projection units, projectile weapons, and numerous other uses | title = Mister Terrific | cvr_image = | cvr_caption = | schedule = Monthly | format = Ongoing | limited = N | ongoing = Y | genre = Superhero | pub_series = DC Comics | 1stishyr = 2011 | 1stishmo = September | endishyr = 2012 | endishmo = April | issues = 8 | main_char_team = | writers = Eric Wallace | artists = Gianluca Gugliotta, Scott Clark, James Taylor | cat = super | subcat = DC Comics | hero = y | sortkey = Mister Terrific | sort_title = Mister Terrific }} '''Michael Holt''' is a [[Character (arts)|fictional character]], a [[superhero]] appearing in [[American comic book]]s published by [[DC Comics]]. He is the second character to take up the '''[[Mister Terrific (comics)|Mister Terrific]]''' mantle. [[Echo Kellum]] currently portrays a version of the character named Curtis Holt / Mister Terrific in the shared DC [[Arrowverse]] show ''[[Arrow (TV series)|Arrow]].'' ==Publication history== Michael Holt was created by [[John Ostrander]] and [[Tom Mandrake]] and first appeared in ''[[Spectre (DC Comics character)|Spectre]]'' (vol. 3) #54 (June 1997). ==Fictional character biography== At a very young age, Michael Holt shows remarkable intelligence, reading and assimilating the works of [[Aage Bohr]], [[Albert Einstein]], [[Max Planck]] and [[Richard Feynman]], the pantheon of theoretical physics.''[[Justice Society of America|JSA]]'' #13, pg.1 Michael grows up with his mentally challenged older brother, Jeffrey, whom he loves dearly. When Jeffrey dies at the age of 15, Michael is devastated.''52'' #39, pg.22 Holt displays "a natural aptitude for having natural aptitudes", as he calls it, easily picking up and retaining complex skills and abilities that others spend their entire lives perfecting. Before he begins his career as a superhero, he already possesses 14 [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D]]s (two in [[engineering]] and [[physics]]—including doctorates and master's degrees in [[law]], [[psychology]], [[chemistry]], [[political science]], and [[mathematics]]''JSA'' #28, pg. 11''JSA'' #53, pg. 8)—is a self-made multi-millionaire with a high tech firm called Cyberwear (subsequently sold to [[Waynetech]]''JSA'' #28, pg. 11), and is a [[gold medal]]-winning [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] [[Decathlon|decathlete]]. The accidental deaths of his wife and unborn child are a devastating blow to Holt. He considers himself responsible for the accident as he made his wife late for church by arguing with her about the value of religion. While contemplating [[suicide]], he is met by the Spectre, who tells him about [[Mister Terrific (Terry Sloane)|Terry Sloane]], the Golden Age superhero known as Mister Terrific. Inspired by Sloane's life story, he takes the name Mister Terrific{{cite book|last=Manning|first= Matthew K.|last2=Dolan|first2=Hannah, ed.|chapter= 1990s|title = DC Comics Year By Year A Visual Chronicle|publisher=[[Dorling Kindersley]] |year=2010 |isbn= 978-0-7566-6742-9 |page= 279 |quote = ''The Spectre'' ongoing series was nearing its end, but that didn't stop writer John Ostrander and artist Tom Mandrake from pooling their creative forces to create one of the DCU's newest shining stars...An inspired and reborn [Michael] Holt then picked up the mantle of Mr. Terrific.}} and later joins the current [[Justice Society of America]] (JSA), eventually serving as its chairman. Initially, he wears ordinary clothes and a leather jacket with Sloane's "Fair Play" emblem on the back. Later, he switches to a T-shaped mask composed of electronic [[nanorobotics|nanite]]s, a black and white costume with red trim, and a collarless jacket in the same colors (the black sections of tunic and jacket forming a "'''T'''") with "Fair Play" written on the sleeves and "Terrific" across the back. For a time, he acts as spokesperson for [[Hourman|Tylerco]] and consults for the company on [[industrial espionage]] and security matters in exchange for it helping fund a youth center Terrific has started.''JSA'' #5, pg.6 Holt has a friendly rivalry with [[Batman]], his opposite number in the [[Justice League|Justice League of America]] (in his identity as Bruce Wayne, Batman owns Holt's business). Holt has encountered Sloane twice through [[time travel]], with Sloane expressing pride in having so worthy a successor. Holt has been noted as the most intelligent member of the JSA in its history, surpassing his predecessor. He is also known as the third-smartest person in the world,''Infinite Crisis'' # 5, pg. 1 and this notion now appears to be widespread within the DC Universe.''Justice Society of America (vol. 3)'' # 2, pg. 3 ===Justice Society of America chairmanship=== During a conflict over leadership of the Justice Society between former chairman [[Hawkman (Carter Hall)|Hawkman]] and then-current chairman [[Sandy Hawkins|Sand]], Terrific is elected as the JSA's new chairman by his teammates, despite not actively seeking the office.''JSA'' #27, pg.17-18 He serves in this capacity until the team disbands following the [[Infinite Crisis]]. Mr. Terrific currently remains a member of the reformed Justice Society of America. He resumed his chairmanship from the last incarnation of the team,''52'' #39, pg. 22, Backup Origin but his leadership responsibilities in Checkmate eventually prompt him to relinquish the position to [[Power Girl]].''Justice Society of America'' (vol. 3) # 4 ===Infinite Crisis=== {{main|Infinite Crisis}} Mr. Terrific is part of the team assembled by Batman for an attack on the [[OMAC (comics)|Brother Eye]] satellite responsible for controlling the OMACs. He plays a critical role as his invisibility to technology allows him to reach the satellite's propulsion system, sending it crashing to Earth. During this time, he meets and befriends another African American superhero—[[Black Lightning]]. ===One Year Later=== {{main|One Year Later}} In the "[[One Year Later]]" storyline, Holt is still a member of the JSA, and he has also become part of the [[United Nations Security Council]]'s intelligence agency, [[Checkmate (comics)|Checkmate]]. He holds the position of White King's Bishop initially, but when the previous White King (Alan Scott) is forced to resign, he becomes Checkmate's new White King, complicating his relationship with [[Sasha Bordeaux]], Checkmate's Black Queen. He has also given up his chairman position, which has been taken over by [[Power Girl]]. Mr. Terrific has also established an ill-defined mentorship with [[Firestorm (comics)|Firestorm]] over the missing year; the specifics of their meeting are yet to be documented. Holt is forced to face his issues with faith once again when the JSA confront [[Gog (DC Comics)#Thy Kingdom Come|Gog]], a God of the Second World. Not only is Gog incapable of hearing Terrific due to his lack of faith, but during a trip to the Earth-Two of the new multiverse, Holt encounters his Earth-Two counterpart, who is now a devout believer after having a religious experience on the day his wife survived her accident. ===Final Crisis=== {{main|Final Crisis}} During the ''Final Crisis of Humanity'', the war between [[Darkseid]] and the human world, Mister Terrific, along with [[Cheetah (comics)|Cheetah]] and [[Snapper Carr]], are left trapped in the ruins of Checkmate headquarters, unable to get past the brainwashed [[metahuman]], and caring for Sasha, who prefers using her [[OMAC (comics)|OMAC]] programming to shut down her bodily functions rather than falling prey to the [[Anti-Life Equation]]. Forcefully waking up Sasha, thus condemning her, Michael Holt has no choice but to activate a new OMAC population, programmed to obey him rather than Brother Eye, and to protect the last few humans against the new [[Justifiers]]. ===Death and return=== In ''Justice Society of America'' vol. 3 series, Mr. Terrific takes over the research, just as the low-level villain Tapeworm appears on the news, taking hostages and demanding that Wildcat show himself. [[Jeremy Karne|All-American Kid]] and [[King Chimera]] must remain in the brownstone, Mister Terrific retreats to his lab, and the rest of the team leaves to help Wildcat. All-American Kid goes into the lab and stabs Mister Terrific in the back, pretending to have been mind controlled.''Justice Society of America'' (vol. 3) #29 (July 2009) Justice Society members arrive back at headquarters to discover Mr. Terrific has been attacked, and [[Dr. Mid-Nite (Pieter Cross)|Dr. Mid-Nite]] tends to his wounds.''Justice Society of America'' (vol. 3) #30 (August 2009) In the end, Mister Terrific succumbs to his injuries and Alan Scott reports that he has died.''Justice Society of America'' (vol. 3) #31 (September 2009) However, Scott is able to use the power of the Green Flame to slow down time around Mister Terrific's body in the hopes that he can be healed before brain death occurs.''Justice Society of America'' (vol. 3) #32 (October 2009) Michael is restored to life by the magic of the new [[Doctor Fate]], and attacks All-American Kid, revealing that he is actually the teenage psychopath known as [[Jeremy Karne|Kid Karnevil]], and subdues him.''Justice Society of America'' (vol. 3) #33 (November 2009) For a short time during his recovery, Michael is forced to use a wheelchair, although he still finds time to upgrade [[Mister America (Jeffrey Graves)|Mister America]]'s whip.''Justice Society of America'' (vol. 3) #34 (December 2009) ===The New 52=== On September 2011, [[The New 52]] rebooted DC's continuity. In this new timeline, Mister Terrific received a self-titled ongoing series written by Eric Wallace and drawn by Roger Robinson.{{cite web|last=Hyde |first=David |url=http://dcu.blog.dccomics.com/2011/06/02/the-new-justice/ |title=The New Justice | DC Comics |publisher=Dcu.blog.dccomics.com |date=2011-06-01 |accessdate=2016-02-04}} Holt begins sporting a new costume designed by [[Cully Hamner]].{{cite web|author=By DCE Editorial |url=http://dcu.blog.dccomics.com/2011/06/09/project-up-up-and-runway/#comments |title=Project: Up Up and Runway | DC Comics |publisher=Dcu.blog.dccomics.com |date=2011-06-09 |accessdate=2016-02-04}} He is also in a relationship with Karen Starr. On January 12, 2012, DC announced that it would be ending six of the lowest selling New 52 titles in April, replacing them with six different titles in the revamp's second wave.{{cite press release|author=Albert Ching|url=http://www.newsarama.com/comics/dc-new-52-new-titles-120112.html|title=Six Titles In, Six Out in 'Second Wave' of DC's NEW 52|publisher=Newsarama|date=January 12, 2012|accessdate=January 23, 2012}} ''Mister Terrific'' was cancelled with issue #8 in April 2012.{{cite press release|author=DC Comics|url=http://www.dccomics.com/dccomics/comics/?dat=20120407|title=On Sale April '12|publisher=DC Comics|accessdate=January 23, 2012}} The series ends with Mister Terrific being displaced to a parallel universe where he continues to appear in the ''[[Earth-Two#The New 52|Earth-2]]'' series.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsarama.com/comics/dc-comics-June-2012-solicitations.html |title=DC Comics' FULL June 2012 Solicitations |publisher=Newsarama.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-04}} ===DC Rebirth=== {{expand section|date=June 2017}} In ''Dark Days: The Forge'', Mister Terrific returns to Earth Prime as Batman unveils a containment unit in The Lunar Batcave bearing the [[Plastic Man]] logo, and suggests it is time to release him.''Dark Days: The Forge'' #1 (June 2017) Mister Terrific stumbles upon [[Simon Stagg]]'s plot to open a portal to the Dark Multiverse with [[Metamorpho]] transmutated to Nth Metal. While trying to get Simon Stagg to close the portal with the help of Plastic Man, Mister Terrific is sucked in to the portal with Plastic Man and Metamorpho as Plastic Man shields them from the Dark Multiverse energy. Upon arriving on a lifeless world, they encounter [[Phantom Girl]] who has been trapped in her intangible form and had no knowledge of sending a signal. When the four of them find a computer in the gut of a dead giant creature, they are greeted by a hologram of [[Tom Strong]] who states that they are needed to save the universe.''The Terrifics'' #1. DC Comics. Mister Terrific, Plastic Man, and Metamorpho learn from Phantom Girl that she was stuck in intangible form since she was a child. After the four of them made it back to their world, Mister Terrific tries to leave the three of them at Simon Stagg's compound only to be drawn back to them.''The Terrifics'' #2. DC Comics. Due to the effects of the Dark Multiverse energy, Mister Terrific concludes that they can't go their separate ways due to this bond. Though Mister Terrific was able to come up with a compromise with Simon Stagg by investigating the bond at his facility. This leads to Mister Terrific to find the Tom Strong that sent left the message and find out how to get untethered by the dark energy.''The Terrifics'' #3. DC Comics. ==Religious beliefs== While being held captive by [[Onimar Synn]] on an adventure with the Justice Society on [[Thanagar]], Holt first expresses his disbelief in souls and that he is uncomfortable with the notion of [[reincarnation]] after witnessing the return of teammate [[Hawkman]]. Holt states, "when my wife, Paula, was killed in a car accident ... she was gone. I didn't feel her 'soul' around me. Didn't feel anything".''JSA'' # 26, pg. 8-9 He later elaborates on this by explaining that his lack of faith extends back prior to his wife's death, and states that he blames himself for her death as he delayed her going to church because the two of them argued about the merits of faith. Holt believes that she would have avoided the accident if she had not been arguing with him. He acknowledges the irony of this given such factors as the Spectre's role in his origin, and his encounter with the likes of the [[Spirit King]], but he still maintains his skepticism about faith and religion. After a [[near-death experience]] where he sees his wife and unborn child (whom he decides to name 'Terry' after the original Mister Terrific), Holt's atheism is shaken and he agrees to attend a church service with teammate [[Doctor Mid-Nite]].''JSA'' # 62, pg. 17-21 However, this attempt to find religion apparently is not satisfying as Holt is also seen getting into a theological discussion with [[Ragman (comics)|Ragman]] during the ''[[Infinite Crisis]]'' (Ragman is [[Judaism|Jewish]] while Mr. Terrific describes himself as an [[atheism|atheist]]). When asked if he has faith in anything, Terrific answered, "Sure I do. I've got faith in my team." During ''Thy Kingdom Come'', when Power Girl is sent back to the Earth-2 pre-Crisis universe, she meets her world's Michael Holt, who is ironically a priest after he has a religious experience. During the same storyline, 'our' Holt told Doctor Mid-Nite that he feels that his issues with faith actually stem from his own inability to understand it, confessing that he ''wants'' to believe but something inside him will not let him. ==Powers, abilities, and equipment== *Holt is described as having "a natural aptitude for having natural aptitudes"; picking up complicated skills quickly and retaining them, such as performing emergency surgery on teammate [[Alan Scott]] after reading about the procedure in a medical textbook and subsequently becoming Dr. Mid-Nite's assistant. As Holt himself put it, "everyone has a talent... Mine is learning."''JSA'' # 17, pg. 1 *Holt is also known as the third-smartest man on Earth. *He is aided by his "T-Spheres", floating robotic spheres with multiple functions, [[holograph]]ic projection,''JSA All-Stars'' # 7, pg.4 projecting [[laser]] grids,''JSA'' # 61, pg.6 and recording, communication, linking with and manipulating other electronic devices, from satellites to electronic locks.''JSA: Classified'' # 29, pg.11 They allow Terrific to fly by bearing his weight,''JSA'' # 78, pg.3 and can be used as weapons, both by exploding with enough force to send [[Captain Marvel (DC Comics)|Captain Marvel]] flying back,''JSA'' # 41, pg.19 generating powerful electric charges,''JSA'' # 31, pg.16 and strike as flying, projectile weapons.''JSA'' # 71, pg.4 They respond to his mental and vocal commands. *He is [[invisibility|invisible]] to all forms of electronic detection. Despite a claim to Black Lightning in ''Infinite Crisis'' that "I've got one superpower: I'm invisible to technology," in all other instances this ability is tied to nanotechnology woven into his specially designed "T-Mask" (which is molecularly bonded to his face and can appear and disappear at will) and costume. Mr. Terrific was apparently the only superhero whom the [[OMAC (comics)|OMACs]] could not detect. The only exception to his invisibility, however, is that of the [[Red Tornado]], who, for reasons yet unknown, is capable of seeing Terrific despite being an android. Red Tornado's status as a sentient wind elemental merely occupying an android body likely explains his ability to see Holt. *Through his mask, Holt can change instantaneously into costume and back again.''JSA'' # 84, pg. 8 His mask also protects his face from chemicals.''JSA All-Stars'' # 7, pg.6 The mask works in conjunction with an earpiece to act as a communications system, and also doubles as an encephalic broadcaster, picking up aggregate thought waves, allowing him to communicate with his T-Spheres, and even project a speaking hologram of himself, even if he is injured or too weak to speak.''JSA'' # 49, pg. 5-6 The mask can also form and transmit images on low- or high-band light frequencies visible to his teammate Doctor Mid-Nite. *He is a black belt in 6 different [[martial arts]] disciplines and an Olympic Gold Medalist in the [[decathlon]].''JSA'' # 12, pg.6 *Holt is also a [[polymath]] who has specialized in multiple fields of medicine, engineering, and science. He possesses fourteen Ph.Ds (two of which are in engineering and physics). * Along with teammate and friend [[Doctor Mid-Nite]] and Batman, Mister Terrific is one of the three main superheroes with medical training in the [[DC Universe]]. Although it is not known if he has an M.D., he did participate in the autopsy of [[Sue Dibny]] in ''[[Identity Crisis (DC Comics)|Identity Crisis]]''.''JSA'' # 67, pg.2-6 *Holt is also [[Polyglotism|polyglot]], though the extent of this hasn't been revealed. He has been shown to speak the languages of the fictional nations of [[Kahndaq]] and [[Bialya]]. Given Holt's propensity for learning, it is likely that he speaks several other languages as well.''Hawkman'' (vol. 3) # 24, pg. 10 ==Other versions== ===Earth-2=== In 2008, an alternate version of Michael Holt from a [[The 52|new]] [[Earth-Two|Earth-2]] appeared in DC stories. This version is a college professor, who has a religious experience after his wife is nearly killed in an accident. This version of Paula Holt is merely left in a coma rather than dying immediately. While contemplating suicide after spending three months trying unsuccessfully to find a cure, he saves another man who is preparing to jump off the same bridge, takes him to a church that was the nearest illuminated building, and the man he saves prays for him. After his wife regains consciousness the following day, this Michael Holt went on to become a devout Christian. He helps the Power Girl of [[List of DC Multiverse worlds#New Earth|New Earth]] to return home.''Justice Society of America'' (vol. 3) #19 When the Justice Society arrives on Earth-2, Professor Holt confronts his counterpart Michael Holt from New-Earth. Professor Holt introduces the Justice Society to his wife, Paula, although New-Earth Michael just introduces himself as Mister Terrific rather than reveal his true name.''Justice Society of America'' (vol. 3) #20 ===Flashpoint=== In the alternate timeline of the ''[[Flashpoint (comics)|Flashpoint]]'' event, Mister and Missus Terrific are framed for unknown crimes when they discover [[Outsider (comics)|Outsider]]'s illicit schemes, and are attempting to assassinate him. Mister and Missus Terrific are both killed by Outsider's guardian statue.''Flashpoint: The Outsider'' #1 (June 2011) ==In other media== ===Television=== ====Live action==== * Michael Holt is mentioned in the ''[[Smallville]]'' episode "[[Absolute Justice]]" (which featured the Justice Society) in the second half by Lois Lane, who mentions that she skipped an interview with him. He is described as a Nobel-winning scientist and tech guru. * A character named '''Curtis Holt''' appears in [[the CW]] series ''[[Arrow (TV series)|Arrow]]'', played by [[Echo Kellum]]. When he is first introduced, Curtis works with [[Felicity Smoak]] at Palmer Technology.{{cite web|last=Abrams |first=Natalie |url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/07/16/arrow-echo-kellum-mr-terrific-season-4 |title='Arrow' casts Mr. Terrific for season 4 |publisher=EW.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-04}} Like his comic book incarnation, he has created the T-spheres and occasionally wears the Fair Play jacket. Curtis is a big fan of [[Green Arrow]], and after learning that Felicity has a connection with him, he is determined to figure out his identity. In the episode "Beacon of Hope", Curtis joins Team Arrow temporarily and learns the members' identities, helping them to defeat the latest attack of [[Bug-Eyed Bandit|Brie Larvan]]. In Season 5, Curtis officially joins Team Arrow and begins training to become a vigilante.{{cite web|last=Mitovich |first=Matt |url=http://tvline.com/2016/04/04/arrow-season-5-echo-kellum-series-regular-curtis/ |title='Arrow Season 5: Echo Kellum Promoted to Series Regular as Curtis |publisher=tvline.com |date= |accessdate=2016-04-05}} As a vigilante, Curtis uses the name "Mr. Terrific", which is a homage to his favorite wrestling champion [[Terry Sloane]], who went by the same name in the ring. This version of the character is [[gay]] and is depicted as having a husband named Paul (perhaps a gender-swapped version of his wife in the comics, who was named Paula). ====Animation==== [[File:MrTerrific.jpg|thumb|right|Mr. Terrific on ''[[Justice League Unlimited]]'' in the episode "Destroyer".]] * Michael Holt has made several [[cameo appearance]]s in the animated TV series ''[[Justice League Unlimited]]''. He moves into a more prominent role in the series' final season, becoming the League's Coordinator and responsible for assigning tasks to the various heroes after [[Martian Manhunter|J'onn J'onzz]] resigns from active duty. The animated Mr. Terrific is voiced by former ''[[Third Watch]]'' star [[Michael Beach]]. It is unknown whether Mr. Terrific retains his invisibility to technology, as throughout the show the image of his face appears on several computer screens. His status as one of the world's smartest men is referred to in his full introductory appearance, and the T-Spheres are used in a subsequent episode. * Michael Holt appears in "Hunted", the premiere episode of ''[[Beware the Batman]]'', where he is voiced by [[Gary Anthony Williams]]. He is depicted as a businessman who is kidnapped along with [[Simon Stagg]] and [[Alfred Pennyworth]] by [[Professor Pyg]] and [[Mister Toad (comics)|Mr. Toad]]. The three of them are rescued by Batman. * Mister Terrific appears in ''[[Justice League Action]]'' episode "The Cube Root", voiced by [[Hannibal Buress]].{{cite web|author=Lucas Siegel |url=http://comicbook.com/dc/2016/06/06/new-justice-league-action-characters-officially-revealed/ |title=New Justice League Action Characters Officially Revealed |publisher=Comicbook.com |date=2016-06-05 |accessdate=2016-09-10}} This version is a former child prodigy who was the college roommate of Martin Stein (who claimed that Mister Terrific based his T-Spheres off his S-Cubes). Mister Terrific was establishing the science center dedicated to him which [[Firestorm (comics)|Firestorm]] attends until it is crashed by [[Calculator (comics)|Calculator]] who hacks into Mister Terrific's T-Spheres. During Mister Terrific and Firestorm's fight with Calculator upon him causing a blackout, Calculator uses the hacked T-Spheres to split Firestorm back into Ronnie Raymond and Martin Stein where the hacked T-Spheres make off with Ronnie Raymond. This causes Mister Terrific and Martin Stein to work together to rescue Ronnie Raymond using the S-Cubes as a diversion so that Martin Stein can combine with Ronnie Raymond in order to form Firestorm. Mister Terrific and Firestorm reclaim control over the T-Spheres, defeat Calculator, and hand him over to the police. In “The Brain Buster”, he is kidnapped along with other highly intelligent heroes and villains to participate in an initially unknown figure’s series of contests to determine who is most intelligent. It is mentioned several times that he is “only” the third-smartest person in the world. In the end, he reveals that he prefers not to call too much attention to himself; he is the one who made the list, and gave himself third place. ===Film=== * In ''[[Justice League: Crisis on Two Earths]]'', a picture of a Parallel Earth version of Mister Terrific, named '''Mister Horrific''', can be seen in [[Joker (character)|the Joker]]'s counterpart computer, as one of [[Superwoman]]'s made men. * An alternate universe version of Michael Holt appears in ''[[Justice League: Gods and Monsters]]'', voiced by [[Arif S. Kinchen]]. He was a scientist who was part of [[Lex Luthor]]'s "Project Fair Play". While meeting with the other scientists (consisting of [[Will Magnus]], [[Steel (John Henry Irons)|John Henry Irons]], [[Bumblebee (comics)|Karen Beecher]], [[Pat Dugan]], [[Doctor Light (Kimiyo Hoshi)|Kimiyo Hoshi]], [[Professor Hamilton|Emil Hamilton]], [[T. O. Morrow|Thomas Morrow]], and [[Stephen Shin]]), Michael Holt is killed with the other scientists, (with the exception for Will Magnus who secretly orchestrated the attack), by the [[Metal Men]]. ===Video games=== * Mr. Terrific makes a background cameo in the video game ''[[Injustice: Gods Among Us]]''. He can be seen in the reactor level of the Watchtower stage. He flies and works on the computer in the center where he is keeping the reactor in check. * Mr. Terrific is a playable in [[Lego DC Super-Villains]] as part of the TV Superheroes Pack ===Miscellaneous=== Michael Holt is featured in the ''[[Smallville|Smallville Season 11]]'' digital comic based on the [[Smallville|TV series]]. ===Toys=== * Mr. Terrific was the third figure released in the [[DC Universe Classics#Wave Eight|eighth wave]] of the [[DC Universe Classics]] line. His accessory was his T-Spheres, which could be placed into his back. * Mr. Terrific has also received a figure in the Target-exclusive Justice League Unlimited line, packaged on a single card. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://worldofblackheroes.com/2011/01/25/mr-terrific-michael-holt/ World of Black Heroes: Mister Terrific (Michael Holt) Biography] *[http://www.dccomics.com/dcu/heroes_and_villains/?hv=origin_stories/mr_terrific&p=1 DCComics.com's Origin of Mister Terrific] *[http://www.dcdatabaseproject.com/wiki/Mister_Terrific_(Michael_Holt) DCDP: Mister Terrific (Michael Holt)] {{Justice Society of America}} [[Category:Characters created by John Ostrander]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1997]] [[Category:DC Comics martial artists]] [[Category:African-American superheroes]] [[Category:Fictional atheists and agnostics]] [[Category:LGBT superheroes]] [[Category:Fictional LGBT characters in television]] [[Category:Fictional gay males]] [[Category:Fictional scientists]] [[Category:Fictional surgeons]]

{{distinguish|text=[[Mohism]], a school of classical Chinese philosophy}} [[File:Zhuang Moism symbol.svg|thumb|200px|A symbol of the religious culture of the Zhuang people. It is an image of god Buluotuo, the great ancestor of the Zhuang nation identified with the Spring of the universe (the Utmost God).{{refn|group=note|Astronomically, the [[Absolute (philosophy)|Principle of the universe]] is represented by the Sun or the [[Pole Star]]—at the center in the Zhuang symbol—, with the [[Big Dipper]] constellation revolving around it—in the Zhuang symbol represented as the birds, points and wavings. The symbol is shown on [[Zhuang drum]]s, monuments and temples.}}]]
'''Mo''' or '''Moism''' ({{zh|c=摩教|p=Mó jiào}}), occasionally called '''Zhuang Shigongism''' ({{zh|c=壮族师公教|p=Zhuàngzú shīgōng jiào|l=Zhuang Ancestral Father Religion}}), is the [[religion]] of most [[Zhuang people]], the largest ethnic minority of [[China]]. It has a large presence in [[Guangxi]]. While it has a [[Supreme Being|supreme god]], the [[creator deity|creator]] [[Bu Luotuo]] (布洛陀),<ref name="shvoong">{{cite web|url=http://www.shvoong.com/business-management/1596580-culture-mo-religion-zhuangs/#ixzz2Tx7qhaPk|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217032006/http://www.shvoong.com/business-management/1596580-culture-mo-religion-zhuangs/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=17 December 2013|title=On the Culture of Mo Religion of Zhuangs|author=[http://www.shvoong.com/writers/tsinghua/ Tsinghua]|date=15 March 2005|accessdate=8 November 2013}} </ref> numerous other deities are venerated as well. It has a three-element-theory (sky, earth and water).<ref name="shvoong"/> Mo is [[animism|animistic]], teaching that spirits are present in everything.<ref name="bonn">{{cite web|url=http://hss.ulb.uni-bonn.de/2012/2832/2832.pdf|title=Das Epos der Zhuang-Nationalität in China: Genese, Überlieferung und Religion|author=Li Jingfeng|year=2012|accessdate=8 November 2013|publisher=Rheinischen Friedrich-Wilhelms-Universität zu Bonn}}</ref>
Mo developed from prehistoric beliefs of the Zhuang people;<ref name="bonn"/> it also has similarities to [[Chinese folk religion]],<ref>Mo Youzheng. 2009-01b.</ref> and has developed similar doctrines to [[Buddhism]] and [[Taoism]], in the process of competition with the influence of these religions on Zhuang culture.<ref>Yang Shuzhe. 2001-04.</ref><ref>Yang Shuzhe. 2002-04.</ref> The [[Cultural Revolution]] of China weakened Mo,<ref name="bonn"/> though the religion has undergone a revival since the 1980s.<ref>He Qimin. 2011-03.</ref><ref>Qin Cong. 2011-01.</ref> Moism varies from region to region.<ref name="bonn"/>
== Beliefs == Mo has a three-element theory (sky, earth and water).<ref name="shvoong"/> The religion is [[Animism|animistic]], teaching that spirits are present in everything.<ref name="bonn"/> The spirits are seen as immortal and subject to changes in mood.<ref name="bonn"/> Mo exhibits [[totemism]] and the cult of reproduction.<ref name="bonn"/>
=== Deities === In Mo, [[Bu Luotuo]] is considered the supreme god, creator and the founder of the religion.<ref name="shvoong"/>
The Flower Mother, [[Me Hoa]], is seen as the creator of humanity and Bu Luotuo's wife. As the goddess of reproduction, she is seen as governing a large garden of golden flowers (boys) and silver flowers (girls). Whoever behaves with good sense and sentiment will receive good flowers (i.e. good children), while those who behave with bad sense receive bad flowers. Families have altars for her.<ref name="bonn"/>
Other gods include [[Tudigong]], who is thought to protect the village; She Shen, who is the village tutelary spirit; the Shan Shen ("god of the mountains"); and the [[Dragon King]].<ref name="every">{{cite web|url=http://www.everyculture.com/Russia-Eurasia-China/Zhuang-Religion-and-Expressive-Culture.html|title=Zhuang - Religion and Expressive Culture|accessdate=8 November 2013|date=n.d.}}</ref> Rice is seen as important;<ref name="bonn"/> there is therefore a field god and a rice god.
=== Cosmology === In Mo, spirits are thought to be present in everything, and even inanimate things such as water are considered to have souls. Mo spirits include deities and ancestors as well as devils.
People are considered to have three souls after death: One goes to the sky, one to the cemetery and one comes back to the deceased’s family. Souls of the dead enter a netherworld but can continue to assist the living.<ref name="every"/> According to the religion, people who have died by violence can become evil spirits.<ref name="every"/>
== Practices == Praying is common within this religion. Sorcerers venerate their masters as well as the founders of witchcraft in their family. There are temples dedicated to land gods. The sun god is celebrated and given offerings.
Mo has the sacred epic ''[[Buluotuo]]'',<ref name="bonn"/> concerning the creation of the universe and life as well as how to live a religiously meritorious life. Its transmission was originally oral.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/102759/102837/7561196.html|title=Buluotuo Scriptures of Zhuang|date=5 August 2011|accessdate=8 November 2013|publisher=People's Daily News|editor=黄蓓蓓}}</ref>
According to Mo, every person is a flower in the garden of [[Molujia]], the goddess of birth.<ref name="bonn"/> On February 29 of the peasants' almanac, the goddess's birthday, women pick flowers and pray to her for pregnancy.<ref name="bonn"/> She is said to have been born in a flower at the beginning of the world.<ref name="bonn"/> There is a festival for her, which varies in place, date and ceremonial procedure.<ref name="bonn"/>
The religion has the custom of burying the dead twice.<ref name="bonn"/> People who have died by violence are cremated to prevent the release of potential malevolent spirits.
=== Shamans and mediums === Mediums, shamans or sorcerers are employed at funerals, to treat disease, and to ward off evil.<ref name="bonn"/>
Mo has female [[shaman]]s, who attempt to treat sickness and communicate with ancestors while in trances.<ref name="every"/> They mostly are recognized as shamans after having had a state similar to trance and claims to have met spirits in this state.<ref name="bonn"/> In rural areas, they are considered [[prophet]]s and [[miracle healer]]s.<ref name="bonn"/> There are also male shamans, who serve at an altar.<ref name="every"/> There are sacrifices of oxen, chickens, and other livestock.<ref name="bonn"/>
=== Domestic worship === A complete family is considered to have three parts: The descendants of the same ancestors, the grave site, and the spirits of the ancestors.<ref name="bonn"/> The spirits of the ancestors are given great consideration and seen as protecting people.<ref name="bonn"/> To return to the sacred world of the ancestors is seen as the greatest end for the deceased.<ref name="bonn"/> Frequently, Mo practitioners have a hall for the ancestors of their homes where ancestors from the past three generations are venerated.<ref name="bonn"/> Such halls are also the site of ancestor worship ceremonies for important festivals, weddings, deaths and births.<ref name="bonn"/> It is not allowed to put dog, cat or snake meat in front of the hall.<ref name="bonn"/> Mo adherents feel a mixture of fear and awe towards their ancestors, believing that their ancestors can support or punish them at will.<ref name="bonn"/> Because they believe their fate is in the hands of their ancestors, the family propitiates the ancestors through prayer and sacrifices.<ref name="bonn"/>
=== Festivals === Mo practitioners celebrate the following festivals of Chinese origin: the [[Chinese New Year|Spring Festival]], the [[Qingming Festival]], the [[Duanwu Festival]], the [[Mid-Autumn Festival]] and the [[Dongzhi Festival]].<ref name="bonn"/> Regular rituals are performed on traditional celebrations prescribed in the yearly calendar.
The supreme deity of Mo is a sky god. There are sacrifices to him on the morning of the new year.
Sanyuesan is a festival, which takes place on the 3rd of March of the lunar calendar and is considered to be as important as Qingming.<ref name="bonn"/> On the same day, before the festival takes place, sacrifices for the ancestors take place and graves are cleaned.<ref name="bonn"/> Adherents sing, and boys keep an eye out for potential female partners.<ref name="bonn"/>
Cattle are seen as holy. The [[Cattle Soul Festival]] is celebrated on the 8th day of the 4th lunar month, which Mo adherents believe is the birthday of the Cattle King.<ref name="bonn"/> On this day, adherents go to their cattle barns and free the animals from their yoke.<ref name="bonn"/>
The [[Frog Festival]] takes place during the 1st lunar month, when people pray for rain and a good harvest.<ref name="bonn"/>
The [[Ghost Festival]] takes several days, and is based on the belief that the deceased can contact their relatives as ghosts or by other supernatural means.<ref name="bonn"/> Families clean their homes carefully and undertake other preparations; then the ghosts are welcomed.<ref name="bonn"/> Finally, families say goodbye to the ghost and burn objects so that the ghosts are supplied in afterlife.<ref name="bonn"/>
